subtests.name: URL: Setting <a://example.net>.protocol = '' The empty string is not a valid scheme. Setter leaves the URL unchanged.
URL: Setting <a://example.net>.protocol = 'B' Upper-case ASCII is lower-cased
URL: Setting <a://example.net>.protocol = 'b,c' Only some punctuation is acceptable
URL: Setting <http://test@example.net>.protocol = 'file' Can’t switch from URL containing username/password/port to file
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.protocol = 'b' Can’t switch from special scheme to non-special
URL: Setting <ssh://me@example.net>.protocol = 'http' Can’t switch from non-special scheme to special
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.protocol = 'https:foo : bar' Stuff after the first ':' is ignored
URL: Setting Test>.protocol = 'view-source+data:foo : bar' Stuff after the first ':' is ignored
URL: Setting <http://foo.com:443/>.protocol = 'https' Port is set to null if it is the default for new scheme.
URL: Setting <unix:/run/foo.socket>.username = 'me' No host means no username

URL: Setting <http://example.net>.username = '�	
 !"#$%&'()*+,-./09:;<=>?@AZ[\]^_`az{|}~Éé' UTF-8 percent encoding with the userinfo encode set.
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.username = '%c3%89té' Bytes already percent-encoded are left as-is.
URL: Setting <unix:/run/foo.socket>.password = 'secret' No host means no password

URL: Setting <http://example.net>.password = '�	
 !"#$%&'()*+,-./09:;<=>?@AZ[\]^_`az{|}~Éé' UTF-8 percent encoding with the userinfo encode set.
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.password = '%c3%89té' Bytes already percent-encoded are left as-is.
URL: Setting <data:text/plain,Stuff>.host = 'example.net' Cannot-be-a-base means no host
URL: Setting <http://example.net:8080>.host = 'example.com' Port number is unchanged if not specified in the new value
URL: Setting <http://example.net:8080>.host = 'example.com:' Port number is unchanged if not specified
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.host = '' The empty host is not valid for special schemes
URL: Setting <view-source+http://example.net/foo>.host = '' The empty host is OK for non-special schemes
URL: Setting <a:/foo>.host = 'example.net' Path-only URLs can gain a host
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.host = '0x7F000001:8080' IPv4 address syntax is normalized
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.host = '[::0:01]:2' IPv6 address syntax is normalized
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.host = '[2001:db8::2]:4002' IPv6 literal address with port, crbug.com/1012416
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.host = 'example.com:80' Default port number is removed
URL: Setting <https://example.net>.host = 'example.com:443' Default port number is removed
URL: Setting <https://example.net>.host = 'example.com:80' Default port number is only removed for the relevant scheme
URL: Setting <http://example.net:8080>.host = 'example.com:80' Port number is removed if new port is scheme default and existing URL has a non-default port
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.host = 'example.com/stuff' Stuff after a / delimiter is ignored
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.host = 'example.com:8080/stuff' Stuff after a / delimiter is ignored
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.host = 'example.com?stuff' Stuff after a ? delimiter is ignored
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.host = 'example.com:8080?stuff' Stuff after a ? delimiter is ignored
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.host = 'example.com#stuff' Stuff after a # delimiter is ignored
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.host = 'example.com:8080#stuff' Stuff after a # delimiter is ignored
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.host = 'example.com\stuff' Stuff after a \ delimiter is ignored for special schemes
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.host = 'example.com:8080\stuff' Stuff after a \ delimiter is ignored for special schemes
URL: Setting <view-source+http://example.net/path>.host = 'example.com\stuff' \ is not a delimiter for non-special schemes, but still forbidden in hosts
URL: Setting <view-source+http://example.net/path>.host = 'example.com:8080stuff2' Anything other than ASCII digit stops the port parser in a setter but is not an error
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.host = 'example.com:8080stuff2' Anything other than ASCII digit stops the port parser in a setter but is not an error
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.host = 'example.com:8080+2' Anything other than ASCII digit stops the port parser in a setter but is not an error
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.host = 'example.com:65535' Port numbers are 16 bit integers
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.host = 'example.com:65536' Port numbers are 16 bit integers, overflowing is an error. Hostname is still set, though.
URL: Setting <http://example.com/>.host = '///bad.com' Leading / is not stripped
URL: Setting <sc://example.com/>.host = '///bad.com' Leading / is not stripped
URL: Setting <data:text/plain,Stuff>.hostname = 'example.net' Cannot-be-a-base means no host
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.hostname = '' The empty host is not valid for special schemes
URL: Setting <view-source+http://example.net/foo>.hostname = '' The empty host is OK for non-special schemes
URL: Setting <a:/foo>.hostname = 'example.net' Path-only URLs can gain a host
URL: Setting <http://example.net:8080>.hostname = '0x7F000001' IPv4 address syntax is normalized
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.hostname = '[::0:01]' IPv6 address syntax is normalized
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.hostname = 'example.com:8080' : delimiter invalidates entire value
URL: Setting <http://example.net:8080/path>.hostname = 'example.com:' : delimiter invalidates entire value
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.hostname = 'example.com/stuff' Stuff after a / delimiter is ignored
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.hostname = 'example.com?stuff' Stuff after a ? delimiter is ignored
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.hostname = 'example.com#stuff' Stuff after a # delimiter is ignored
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.hostname = 'example.com\stuff' Stuff after a \ delimiter is ignored for special schemes
URL: Setting <view-source+http://example.net/path>.hostname = 'example.com\stuff' \ is not a delimiter for non-special schemes, but still forbidden in hosts
URL: Setting <http://example.com/>.hostname = '///bad.com' Leading / is not stripped
URL: Setting <sc://example.com/>.hostname = '///bad.com' Leading / is not stripped
URL: Setting <http://example.net:8080>.port = '' Port number is removed if empty is the new value
URL: Setting <http://example.net:8080>.port = '80' Default port number is removed
URL: Setting <https://example.net:4433>.port = '443' Default port number is removed
URL: Setting <https://example.net>.port = '80' Default port number is only removed for the relevant scheme
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.port = '8080/stuff' Stuff after a / delimiter is ignored
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.port = '8080?stuff' Stuff after a ? delimiter is ignored
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.port = '8080#stuff' Stuff after a # delimiter is ignored
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.port = '8080\stuff' Stuff after a \ delimiter is ignored for special schemes
URL: Setting <view-source+http://example.net/path>.port = '8080stuff2' Anything other than ASCII digit stops the port parser in a setter but is not an error
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.port = '8080stuff2' Anything other than ASCII digit stops the port parser in a setter but is not an error
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.port = '8080+2' Anything other than ASCII digit stops the port parser in a setter but is not an error
URL: Setting <http://example.net/path>.port = '65535' Port numbers are 16 bit integers
URL: Setting <http://example.net:8080/path>.port = '65536' Port numbers are 16 bit integers, overflowing is an error
URL: Setting <non-special://example.net:8080/path>.port = '65536' Port numbers are 16 bit integers, overflowing is an error
URL: Setting <foo://somehost/some/path>.pathname = '' Non-special URLs can have their paths erased
URL: Setting <foo:///some/path>.pathname = '' Non-special URLs with an empty host can have their paths erased
URL: Setting <foo:/some/path>.pathname = '' Path-only URLs cannot have their paths erased
URL: Setting <foo:/some/path>.pathname = 'test' Path-only URLs always have an initial slash
URL: Setting <http://example.net/home?lang=fr#nav>.pathname = '\a\%2E\b\%2e.\c' \ is a segment delimiter for 'special' URLs
URL: Setting <view-source+http://example.net/home?lang=fr#nav>.pathname = '\a\%2E\b\%2e.\c' \ is *not* a segment delimiter for non-'special' URLs

URL: Setting <a:/>.pathname = '�	
 !"#$%&'()*+,-./09:;<=>?@AZ[\]^_`az{|}~Éé' UTF-8 percent encoding with the default encode set. Tabs and newlines are removed.
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.pathname = '%2e%2E%c3%89té' Bytes already percent-encoded are left as-is, including %2E outside dotted segments.
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.pathname = '?' ? needs to be encoded
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.pathname = '#' # needs to be encoded
URL: Setting <sc://example.net>.pathname = '?' ? needs to be encoded, non-special scheme
URL: Setting <sc://example.net>.pathname = '#' # needs to be encoded, non-special scheme
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.pathname = '/?é' ? doesn't mess up encoding
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.pathname = '/#é' # doesn't mess up encoding
URL: Setting <data:/nospace>.pathname = 'space ' Non-special URLs with non-opaque paths percent-encode U+0020

URL: Setting <a:/>.search = '�	
 !"#$%&'()*+,-./09:;<=>?@AZ[\]^_`az{|}~Éé' UTF-8 percent encoding with the query encode set. Tabs and newlines are removed.
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.search = '%c3%89té' Bytes already percent-encoded are left as-is
URL: Setting <data:space ?query>.search = '' Drop trailing spaces from trailing opaque paths
URL: Setting <data:space  ?query#fragment>.search = '' Do not drop trailing spaces from non-trailing opaque paths

URL: Setting <a:/>.hash = '�	
 !"#$%&'()*+,-./09:;<=>?@AZ[\]^_`az{|}~Éé' Simple percent-encoding; tabs and newlines are removed
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.hash = 'a�b' Percent-encode NULLs in fragment
URL: Setting <non-spec:/>.hash = 'a�b' Percent-encode NULLs in fragment
URL: Setting <http://example.net>.hash = '%c3%89té' Bytes already percent-encoded are left as-is

URL: Setting <data:space                                                                                                                                  #fragment>.hash = '' Drop trailing spaces from trailing opaque paths
URL: Setting <data:space  ?query#fragment>.hash = '' Do not drop trailing spaces from non-trailing opaque paths
